After watching several of these "explanations", and considering the problem, I see the logical failure here. Let's use a deck of cards because it's easier to understand with more than 3 choices. Most people are thinking of it this way: if the player chooses 1 card and the dealer exposes a losing card, the choice is between the player's 1 card and the remaining 50 cards. If you switch to the 50 card pile (minus the player's card and the exposed card), you have a 50 in 52 chance of winning (NOT a 51 in 52, as people think in the 3-door example because the exposed card/door is out of play). But that's not the game. The game is the dealer spreads out all 52 cards. The player chooses 1. The dealer then flips over a card. If the card is the A♠, the player loses. If not, then the player can either keep their card or choose ONE of the remaining 50, giving the player a 1 in 50 chance of picking the correct card, whether they keep their card or picks another. The player's chance doesn't change by switching cards, ALL of the cards have a 1 in 50 chance of being the correct card. Each time the dealer exposes a card, that card is out of play, so the player's chance of winning goes up, but only slightly. But the player's chance of winning never exceeds 50%. The player has a 1 in 52 chance of losing in the first round (if the dealer exposes the A♠, but that doesn't mean the player has a 51 in 52 chance of winning. If the player's card is exposed at this point, they still only have a 1 in 51 chance of it being correct. If they switch cards, that card still only has a 1 in 51 chance of being the correct card.

Each round, if only losing cards are exposed, the player's chance of losing decreases, but only by 1 in the number of items left. In the last round, the player still only has a 1 in 2 chance of winning, not a 50 in 52. Those other 50 cards have been removed from the equation as they are exposed.

Let's extrapolate this back to the "3-doors" example. The player chooses 1 door. A (ONLY ONE) losing door is exposed, which takes it out of play for the next round. In round 2, the player is still left with a 1 in 2 chance of choosing the correct door, whichever door they choose.

O problema de Monty Hall
O paradoxal problema denominado de Monty Hall devido ao apresentador do programa
de televisão que o exibia em seu show de prêmios é equivalente ao seguinte problema:
Em uma urna há uma bola branca e duas bolas pretas; uma pessoa retira aleatoriamente
uma bola da urna.
i) Qual a probabilidade da bola branca permanecer na urna?
ii) Qual a probabilidade da bola retirada ser a bola branca?
Vemos que se trata de um problema muito fácil. O espaço amostral referente à primeira
pergunta consiste de três elementos, a saber, a bola branca é retirada e ficam duas bolas
pretas na urna, uma bola preta é retirada e ficam na urna uma preta e uma branca, a
segunda bola preta é retirada e permanece na urna uma branca e outra preta. Logo, a
probabilidade da bola branca permanecer na urna é 2/3. Não há paradoxo algum. Nem
aparente contradição ou contra-senso.
A probabilidade de se retirar a bola branca é evidentemente 1/3.
Formulemos agora o problema com três bolas pretas em vez de duas. Suponha que uma
urna contenha quatro bolas, uma branca e três pretas. O candidato ao prêmio retira
aleatoriamente uma bola. Em seguida o apresentador retira duas bolas pretas da urna. O
candidato então retira pela segunda vez e aleatoriamente outra bola da urna. Não há
reposição de bolas. O candidato ganha o prêmio se retirar nesta segunda vez a bola
branca.
i) Qual a probabilidade da segunda bola retirada pelo candidato ser branca?
ii) Qual a probabilidade da primeira bola retirada pelo candidato ser branca?
A segunda pergunta é trivial: a probabilidade é 1/4.
A primeira pergunta também não é tão difícil de ser respondida. Vamos identificar o
espaço amostral. Suponha que o candidato retire a bola branca; em seguida o
apresentador retira duas pretas. Sobra na urna uma única bola preta para ser retirada
pelo candidato. Se o candidato retirar pela primeira vez uma bola preta, o apresentador
retirará as duas bolas pretas restantes e aí sobra a bola branca para a segunda retirada do
candidato. Vemos que o espaço amostral é constituído por quatro elementos, a saber:
(branca - preta); (preta - branca); (preta - branca) e (preta - branca). Logo a
probabilidade do candidato retirar a bola branca na segunda vez é 3/4. A probabilidade
de o candidato ganhar o prêmio na primeira situação é três vezes maior do que na
segunda situação.

Vejamos o conhecido problema das três caixas proposto por Joseph Bertrand em 1889.
Considere três caixas. Uma delas contém duas moedas douradas, a segunda contém
duas moedas prateadas e a terceira uma dourada e outra prateada. Uma caixa é escolhida
aleatoriamente e também aleatoriamente é retirada uma moeda de dentro dessa caixa
que foi escolhida. Suponha que a moeda retirada seja dourada. A pergunta é: qual a
probabilidade da outra moeda que está dentro dessa caixa escolhida ser também
dourada? Algo me causa espanto quando ouço que o senso comum tem como resposta
probabilidade igual a 1/2. Ora, não há senso comum ou mesmo bom senso em
probabilidade. A teoria é bem estabelecida e quando se faz uma pergunta sobre
probabilidade não recorremos ao bom senso, recorremos à determinação do espaço
amostral e do subconjunto evento. Aliás, o que significa bom senso ou senso comum?
Absolutamente nada, apenas delírio, um carão oco de uma modelo ou de um efeminado.
Temos três caixas. Se a primeira for escolhida teremos duas possibilidades, a saber:
(D1, D2) e (D2, D1).

Se a segunda caixa for escolhida teremos mais duas possibilidades:
(P1, P2) e (P2, P1).
Em que P1 é uma moeda prateada e P2 é a outra moeda prateada.
Se a terceira caixa for escolhida teremos ainda duas outras possibilidades:
(D, P) e (P, D).
Aqui, D é uma moeda dourada e P é uma moeda prateada. A primeira coordenada
significa a retirada de uma moeda e a segunda coordenada significa a moeda que ficou
na caixa.
Bem, em princípio nosso espaço amostral se constitui de seis elementos. Assim, temos
seis possibilidades. Porém, é necessário lembrar que algumas possibilidades já
aconteceram quando a moeda dourada foi retirada. Como não pode deixar de acontecer
o que já aconteceu, nosso espaço amostral fica reduzido aos seguintes elementos:
{(D1, D2), (D2, D1), (D, P)}.
Qual é então a probabilidade da moeda que ficou na caixa ser dourada? Olhamos o

The way I think about the Monty Hall problem is like this. Choose a door between 1 and 3. You chose door 1. That door IS your choice, and is now part of the IS category. The IS category has a 1 (# of chosen doors) over 3 (Total # of doors) or 1/3 chance of having your cash prize.


Any one of the other doors IS NOT your choice, and therefore, belongs to the IS NOT category. Now the IS NOT category has a simple calculation for probability: 2 (Total # of IS NOT doors) over 3 (Total # of doors), or 2/3. This number is important, because we will manipulate numbers within the IS NOT category, and that number (2/3) will convert probability within the category to total probability. We will call this the IS NOT Multiplier.


Now, since the host will never interact with the IS category, we can forget about it for a while and just look at the IS NOT category. In order to calculate the probability of any door in relation to the total, we just multiply its probability within the IS NOT category with the IS NOT Multiplier. For example, the probability of door 3 (as of right now) is 1 (# of chosen doors within IS NOT) over 2 (Total # of IS NOT doors that can have the prize) or 1/2 in the IS NOT category. Total probability is 1/2 (from before) times the IS NOT Multiplier, which crosses out "Total # of IS NOT doors" found in the denominator of the local probability and the numerator of the IS NOT Multiplier. So, 1/2 * 2/3 = 1/3, which we recognize as the probability of the door on its own.


Now, when door 3 is revealed to actually be hiding a penguin, the odds change in the IS NOT category. Door 3 now has 0 chance of holding the cash, leaving door two to fill the gap in the IS NOT category. In other words, door 2's probability (within the IS NOT category) is now 1 (# of chosen doors within IS NOT) over 1 (Total # of IS NOT doors that can have the prize) or 1, since we know that door 3 cannot have that prize.


Finally, multiply this by the IS NOT Multiplier to get a result of 2/3 overall probability for that one door. This math can be extended to higher door problems, like if you needed to choose a door out of 5 and the host reveals 2 doors. that would be a IS of 1/5, and IS NOT of 4/5, and each remaining door (non-revealed door) in the IS NOT category 2/5 (there being two of them). 2/5 + 2/5 + 1/5 = 1, so the probabilities add up.

Here is the thing: The Monty Hall Problem requires that the host do the following:
1) If the player chooses a goat, the host will pick the other goat
2) If the player chooses the car, the host will pick a goat at random

This means that during the host's turn, he or she will NEVER pick the car, and will ALWAYS pick a goat. It is no longer random. Therefore, your original choice still has a 1/3 chance of having the car, but the other door now has a 2/3 chance of holding the car, because the elimination just weighted the game in it's favor.

Let's run through it. The player picks door 1 and the host picks door 2. Door 2 is opened revealing a goat. Since we know door 2 doesn't contain the car, we are down to two possibilities:
1) the host HAD to pick door 2 as the player picked the other goat
2) the player already choose the car and the host could choose either door

Since the player only has a 1/3 chance of picking the car, the first scenario is more likely than the second. In other words, if the player picks door 1, then the host opens door 2, door 3 has a 2/3 chance of containing the car.

The 50/50 idea is making the unspoken assumption that the host is picking a door at random that just happened to have a goat. If this is the case (ignoring the unanswered scenario of what happens if the host picks the car) then the odds would indeed be 50% for each door. But the host's non-random choice changes the game.

I think we can all agree that this problem relies totally on probability. You are given a 1/3 to pick the car on your first try. However, once Monty reveals a goat, the two remaining doors do NOT hold a 1/2 chance of containing the car. Why? Fractions.

So, let's talk about these fractions. We can use the fraction 1/3 for an example. The first number, 1 in this case, is called a numerator, and the second is called the denominator. All three doors hold equal chances, 1/3, of containing the car. And the other two doors hold the other 2/3 of the equation. A rule in mathematics prevents the following from happening: once the numerator changes, the denominator does not. In other words, taking out one of the unselected doors can modify the top number, but not the bottom number. The only way to modify the denominator is to multiply or divide, which the subtraction of a door does not do.

Lemme explain this in layman's terms:
0) First, let's reiterate the problem: You're given 3 doors and only one door is good. After you've picked a door, a bad door is removed and you're given an option to swap your pick. Let's call this game [X]

1) Since there are 2 bad doors and 1 good door, your chance of picking one of the bad doors is twice that of the good door.

2) After you've picked a door, and one bad door has been removed, the door you've picked are still twice as likely to be a bad door. Adding or removing doors does not change this fact since the decision was made when you had three doors to choose from.

3) Since your pick is twice as likely to be bad, swapping for the other door, as a result, is twice as likely to be good.

4) The act of swapping, IN THIS PARTICULAR CASE, is a complete reversal: where good becomes bad and bad become good. It is as if there were 2 good doors and only one bad door. So which game would you play? Game [A] with 3 doors where 1 door has rewards OR game [B] with 3 doors where 2 doors has rewards (the reversed ratio of game [A])? If you do not swap, you're playing game [A]. If you swap you're playing game [B]. Think of game [A] and [B] as 2 different modes of game [X].

If you're still not convinced, keep reading. 

5) What if you're presented with only 2 doors from the get go, no door is removed and I'm giving the chance to swap after I've picked one? Well you've guessed it, your chance is 50/50 whether you swap or not. The reversal effect of swapping discussed in #4 still takes place but a reversal of 50/50 is still 50/50. Let's call this game [C].

6) Then what the difference between game [C] and the swapping phase of game [X]? In the swapping phase of game [X], if you pick RANDOMLY (between swapping and not swapping), it's the exact same game as game [C]. However, you're NOT picking randomly, you actually know which door is twice as likely to be bad. This is what confuses people the most (myself included) as we always think of probability problems like this with 100% random picking.

7) As you may wonder how does the act of removing a bad door make the swap worth it? First of all, if no door is removed, swapping your bad door does not always result in a good door. That is, the reversal effect of swapping (point #4) wouldn't happen if a bad door isn't removed. Second of all, remember that they CANNOT remove the door you've picked NOR the good door. If you have doors X, Y and Z; you pick door X; door Y is removed, then you're left with door X and door Z. This is where the magic happens: by deduction, you know that door X was not removed because you'd picked it, whether it was good or bad did not matter. This gives you no information on which of the two doors to favor. Door Z, on the other hand, was not removed because chances are it's the good door. In other words, door Z has gone through the "Test of removing" which rises it chance of being the good door (more precisely double its chance of being the good door). With this information, you shouldn't play game [C] (i.e. decide whether to swap by flipping the coin). Instead, you swap for door Z.
